section.title: Coding Exercises
section.p: Program listings can be more that just live demonstrations, they can be exercises. The first two also occur in the sample article where they just get a static rendering, if at all.

exercise.title: Inline Coding Exercise, No Help

statement.p: An exercise might ask a reader to write a computer program, that would go here in the statement. But you can also add a program element after a statement. Here we place no code at all, but we do say we want it to be interactive. The purpose is to make it a live coding environment for a version of your output that allows the reader to perhaps submit a solution. The program element is necessary so you can specify a programming language.

exercise.hint: We didn't really ask you to do anything.

statement.p: Similar to above, but we provide a starting point for the exercise.

Similar to above, but now as an activity. This demonstrates the possibility to use any project-like block (project, activity, exploration, investigation), but not in the case when structured with task.

exercise.title: An Exercise with a Static Program

statement.p: Similar to above, again, but we place the program element inside the statement, not after it as a peer. This signals that this is not a coding exercise and the program will render static, since it is explicitly labeled as not being interactive.

section.title: YouTube Videos
section.p: Runestone uses a YouTube API that broadcasts events when a reader interacts with a video. In this way, Runestone can record video-watching as an activity. As output we concede better behavior on small screens (responsiveness) to enable this feature in a Runestone version. Various features, such as playlists, are not yet supportedmake a request.
The margins here are asymmetric just as a test. And this text is here to see where the video ends.
